title: my-ebook
section: 2.1 Introduction: What this course is about
text:
2.1 Introduction: What this course is about
This course provides an introduction to Bayesian data analysis using the probabilistic programming language Stan.
We will use a front end software package called brms.
This course is for:

Linguistics (MM5, MM6)
Cognitive Systems
Cognitive Science

Please see the PULS FAQs to find out how the sign-up system works (in German).
We will be using the software R and RStudio, so make sure you install these on your computer.
Topics to be covered:

Basic probability theory, random variable theory (including jointly distributed RVs), probability distributions (including bivariate distributions)
Using Bayesâ€™ rule for statistical inference
An introduction to (generalized) linear models
An introduction to hierarchical models
Measurement error models
Mixture models
Model selection and hypothesis testing (Bayes factor and k-fold cross-validation)

title: my-ebook
text:
2.2 Teaching
Science and statistics is/are one unitary thing; you cannot do one without the other. Towards this end, I teach some (in my opinion) critically important classes that provide a solid statistical foundation for doing research in cognitive science. Free online course, four weeks (MOOC), enrollments open: Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis. Short (four-hour) tutorial on Bayesian statistics, taught at EMLAR 2022: here Introduction to (frequentist) statistics Introduction to Bayesian data analysis for cognitive science BDA cover

title: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
3 Chapter 1: Welcome and Course Overview
This course offers an introduction to statistics through the RKWard graphical interface of R. Aimed at learners from diverse backgrounds, the course emphasizes practical application over theory. You donâ€™t need a strong background in math or computingâ€”just an eagerness to learn.
Pre-Requisites:
crumbs: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)

title: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
14.1 1. Histogram

Depicts the distribution of a single variable

Can include frequency, relative frequency, and cumulative frequency

Best for understanding where most data points lie
crumbs: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)

title: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
14.2 2. Pie Chart

Represents categorical data as slices of a circle

Best when visualizing proportions
crumbs: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)

title: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
14.3 3. Scatter Plot

Plots two variables to examine relationships

X-axis: Independent variable

Y-axis: Dependent variable

Useful in exploring associations or potential causality
crumbs: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)

title: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
14.4 4. Box Plot

Shows data distribution via quartiles

Median, interquartile range (IQR), and outliers are clearly indicated

Useful for comparing multiple variables
crumbs: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)

title: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
14.5 5. Density Plot

Smoothed version of a histogram

Better suited for continuous data with decimal variation

Key Tips:

JP_01 was frequently used as an example variable

RKWard allows saving and exporting plots easily

GUI menus guide the user through plot creation


Always choose the plot type that best matches your data and goal: frequency, relationship, or comparison.
crumbs: 2Â  Introduction to Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
4 ğŸ“˜ Lecture 05: Essential Math for Statistics
This lecture lays the foundation of mathematical concepts essential to understanding statistics. Topics include coordinate geometry, linear and exponential functions, and basics of calculus.

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
4.1 ğŸ“Œ Key Concepts

4.1.1 ğŸ“ Number Line & Coordinate Geometry

A number line represents a variableâ€™s values.
Cartesian plane: X-axis (independent), Y-axis (dependent).
Linear equation: \(Y = mX + C\), where:

\(m = \frac{Y_2 - Y_1}{X_2 - X_1}\) (slope)
\(C\) is the Y-intercept (Y when X = 0)




4.1.2 ğŸ“Š Exponential Functions

Form: \(Y = a^X\) or \(Y = e^X\) (where \(e \approx 2.718\))
Models rapid, nonlinear growth.



4.1.3 ğŸ§® Differentiation

Measures instantaneous rate of change: \[
\frac{dY}{dX} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(X + h) - f(X)}{h}
\]



4.1.4 ğŸ“ˆ Integration

Calculates area under the curve: \[
\bar{X} = \int X \cdot f(X) \, dX
\]

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
5.1 ğŸ“Œ Definitions

Mean: Arithmetic average; sensitive to outliers.
Median: Middle value; robust to outliers.
Mode: Most frequent value; best for categorical data.

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
5.2 ğŸ” Characteristics

Simple, uses all values (mean).
Median is stable against extreme values.
Mode is useful for nominal data.

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
5.3 ğŸ’¡ Suitability by Data Type



Measure
Data Type




Mean
Interval/Ratio


Median
Ordinal


Mode
Nominal

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
5.4 ğŸ“‰ Skewness

Positive skew: Mean > Median
Negative skew: Mean < Median

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
6.1 ğŸ“Œ Measures

Range: Max - Min
Interquartile Range (IQR): \(Q_3 - Q_1\)
Variance: Avg. of squared deviations
Standard Deviation (SD): \(\sqrt{\text{Variance}}\)
Coefficient of Variation (CV): \(\frac{SD}{Mean}\)

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
6.2 ğŸ“ Theoretical Moments



Moment
Interpretation




1st
Mean


2nd
Variance


3rd
Skewness


4th
Kurtosis

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
7.1 ğŸ§® Mean-Centering

Subtract mean from each data point.
New mean becomes zero.

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
7.2 ğŸ“Š Standardization (Z-Score)

Formula: \(Z = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma}\)
Mean = 0, SD = 1
Unitless; allows comparison across distributions.

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
7.3 ğŸ“Œ Applications

Normalize different scales
Preprocessing in statistics and ML

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
8.1 ğŸ“Œ Key Concepts

Experiment: Controlled process
Event: Subset of outcomes
Sample Space (S): All possible outcomes

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
8.2 ğŸ“ˆ Basic Rule

\(P(A) = \frac{\text{Favorable outcomes}}{\text{Total outcomes}}\)

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
8.3 ğŸ§  Properties

\(0 \leq P(A) \leq 1\)
\(P(S) = 1\)
\(P(A^c) = 1 - P(A)\)
If \(A \subseteq B\), then \(P(A) \leq P(B)\)

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
8.4 ğŸ§® Visual Aids

Venn diagrams
Frequency â†”ï¸ Probability distribution linkage

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
9.1 ğŸ² Bernoulli Trials

Success (p) or failure (1 â€“ p)

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
9.2 ğŸ“Š Binomial Distribution

\(n\) independent trials
\[
P(X = r) = \binom{n}{r} p^r (1-p)^{n-r}
\]

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
9.3 ğŸ“ˆ Properties

Mean: \(np\)
Variance: \(np(1-p)\)

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
9.4 ğŸ® Tools

Galton board
Pascalâ€™s triangle

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
10.1 ğŸ“Œ Characteristics

Bell-shaped, symmetric about \(\mu\)
Area under curve = 1
Emerges with large samples

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
10.2 ğŸ“‰ Equation
\[
f(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2\pi}} e^{-\frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}}
\]

title: 3Â  Basic Statistics Using GUI-R (RKWard)
text:
10.3 ğŸ§® Z-Score

\(Z = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma}\)
